awd_titl_txt: Planning IUCRC at Georgia Institute of Technology:  Center for [Digital Composite Joining and Repair]
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a planning workshop for a new Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) aimed at improving composite material joining and repair (CJAR) technologies. Composite materials are vital to the health and competitiveness of several important industry sectors, including automotive, manufacturing, energy, and aerospace. As composites involve different compositions and element concentration/orientation and tolerances that vary widely, current CJAR practices are highly specialized, labor-intensive, and require experienced technicians to complete the critical inspection, maintenance and repair jobs. Partner institutions including Georgia Institute of Technology, Oakland University, and the University of Tennessee-Knoxville will work collaboratively with various industrial companies, in the automotive, aerospace, energy, and bio-medical sectors of the US economy. The Georgia Tech Site of D-CJAR will primarily work with firms in materials (Chomarat, Henkel, Owens Corning), aerostructures manufacturing (Boeing, Fokker Aerostructures, Lockheed Martin), system operators/maintenance providers (AFSC-Robins AFB, Delta), and equipment vendors (Optomec, Siemens). Faculty and student teams at the partner universities will work with industry members to conduct precompetitive research to develop and disseminate basic and applied technologies/knowledge to facilitate rapid, reliable, and cost-effective composite joining and repair, with an overall goal of significantly reducing costs, cycle time, and variation of CJAR operations within ten (10) years.

With the goal of transforming the current labor-intensive and specialized processes into science-based, automated, digital CJAR processes, the Georgia Tech Site of D-CJAR will primarily focus on developing CJAR technologies for maintenance, repair, and overhaul of aerostructures, automobiles, and infrastructure. We expect advances in several fields and knowledge domains around CJAR, including (1) design and analysis, (2) materials and process engineering, (3) testing and NDE, and (4) data analytics. We will apply diverse advanced digital techniques, including advanced computational modeling, sensing, materials characterization, and machine learning to practical CJAR cases that will also advance the education and workforce preparedness of students working on projects at the partner universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this planning grant is to begin the process of forming the Digital Composite Joining and Repair (D-CJAR) Center with university partners, Georgia Institute of Technology, Oakland University, and the University of Tennessee/Knoxville, and perspective industry members. The specific tasks are to plan, prepare and hold a planning meeting to discuss and agree on an initial research agenda to start the proposed IUCRC. With the planning award from NSF, the Georgia Tech team conducted a 90-day customer discovery effort and planned and held a planning meeting in March 2019. Through these venues, the team collected valuable feedback and comments from industry, and accordingly they refined the mission and scope of the D-CJAR Center and proposed highly relevant research projects for the Phase-I proposal. Specific research areas identified and refined during the planning grant for GT Site of D-CJAR include (1) advancement of weak/kissing bond detection, (2) composite material characterization/compatibility for joining via data-driven manufacturing/testing, (3) Bayesian process control, hybrid modeling and machine learning, and (4) advanced non-destructive inspection.

For the customer discovery effort, the team conducted 35 person-to-person interviews with companies relevant to the composites industry. These interviews helped define and refine the areas of focus for the Center. The primary value proposition for the Georgia Tech site is determined to:

- Offer opportunities to collaborate on developing and gaining access to pre-competitive and cutting-edge technologies via D-CJAR projects and leverage industry dollars by sponsorship from other industry partners and NSF (with very a low overhead rate);
- Provide cost-effective access to state-of-the-art R&D facilities and testbeds within the D-CJAR Center;
- Identify workforce training requirements in the important area and opportunities to interact with potential employees by working with D-CJAR sponsored students;
- Provide a CJAR technology repository and technology investment priority guide via DCJAR technology roadmaps; and
- Offer networking opportunities to interact and collaborate with other leaders in the CJAR community. 

The planning meeting was held on March 5-6, 2019 at Georgia Tech's Wardlaw Center, in Atlanta, GA. The meeting was jointly held by the two university partners, Oakland University and University of Tennessee/Knoxville. Among the 80+ participants at the planning meeting, there were 41 participants from industry companies and governmental agencies (including national labs) of targeted industry sectors of D-CJAR.  Vision, Capabilities and Value Proposition of the D-CJAR Center were presented by the Center and Site Directors, and then discussed. The participants reached a general agreement that the documents are suitable for the D-CJAR center. Georgia Tech faculty presented three sample projects. These projects were selected based on the survey to industry collaborators through the customer discovery process. All the three projects were highly ranked with a large number of positive comments/remarks from the meeting participants. From the industry feedback and comments, it can be seen that the industrial participants consider these projects address industry needs well, are highly innovative, and can generate long term benefits to industry. 

With the planning grant, the vision, mission and research thrusts of the proposed D-CJAR Center have been developed, refined and confirmed. They align and resonate well with industry as evidenced by the data collected both from the customer discovery effort and from the planning meeting. The proposed D-CJAR IUCRC will address critical needs from the composite industry. The development of new materials and processes with tailorable characteristics for composites repair would facilitate standardization, modeling and automation, leading to significantly reduced cycle time and enhanced joining and repair performance for industry. Applying to air transportation, this transfers to speedy repair, less and shorter delays, substantial cost reduction, and more reliable and safer aircraft. Likewise, the automotive industry will greatly benefit from the outcomes of D-CJAR by enjoying rapid repair processes and standardized materials and tools for body and structural repairs. Active collaboration with our industry partners will ensure relevance to education and training of the future workforce to expedite the development and adoption of new technologies in D-CJAR fields. Of particular note is the inclusion of industrial partners from across the entire composite supply chain to ensure performance and translation of research. The establishment of a center to accelerate the D-CJAR technologies will ensure US's global leadership in this growing industry sector.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Chun (Chuck) Zhang
